claim.statement_location: Abstract and Conclusion sections (study framing and concluding discussion describing that reducing working time could mitigate climate change and yield social benefits)
claim.study_type: Observational (sub-national panel analysis of U.S. states, 2007–2013)

data.source: State-level CO2 emissions from US EPA (based on US Department of Energy fuel consumption data); average weekly working hours from US Bureau of Labor Statistics Current Employment Statistics (CES).
data.wave_or_subset: Annual observations for all 50 U.S. states, years 2007–2013 (balanced panel).
data.access_details: Data sources are public government datasets (US EPA emissions inventory, US DOE fuel consumption data, BLS CES). Specific access links or restrictions not provided in the paper summary.
data.notes: Balanced panel of 50 states over 2007–2013. Emissions measured as state-level CO2 from fossil fuel combustion in million metric tons (MMTCO2). Working hours measured as average weekly working hours per worker. No file-level encoding or column-format issues reported in the summary.

method.description: The study compiles a balanced panel of annual state-level CO2 emissions and average weekly working hours for all 50 U.S. states from 2007–2013 and estimates the relationship between working hours and emissions using panel regression techniques. Models include fixed effects and random effects specifications, Prais-Winsten models with panel-corrected standard errors for fixed effects, and hybrid models to separate within- and between-state effects. A set of economic, political, and demographic control variables are included, and robustness/sensitivity checks are performed.
steps: Collect state-level CO2 emissions data (US EPA / US DOE) and average weekly working hours (BLS CES) for each state for years 2007–2013.

Assemble a balanced panel dataset of 50 states × 7 years (350 observations) and compile control variables (population, manufacturing % GDP, energy production, working-age population %, household size, labor productivity, employment-population ratio, GDP per hour/capita, state environmentalism scores, etc.).
Estimate panel regression models: fixed effects and random effects to assess the association between average weekly working hours and state CO2 emissions.
Estimate Prais-Winsten models with panel-corrected standard errors (PCSEs) for fixed-effects specifications to address serial correlation and panel heteroskedasticity.
Estimate hybrid models (within-between decomposition) to separate within-state (over-time) and between-state effects of working hours on emissions.
Assess scale and composition effects by specifying models targeting each effect and comparing coefficients.
Conduct sensitivity analyses and robustness checks (including checks for influential outliers) and report consistency of results across model specifications.
method.models: Panel regression models including fixed effects and random effects, Prais-Winsten models with panel-corrected standard errors (PCSEs) for FE specifications, and hybrid (within-between) models. Elasticities reported (log-log specifications).
method.outcome_variable: State-level carbon dioxide emissions from fossil fuel combustion (measured in million metric tons of CO2, MMTCO2).
method.independent_variables: Primary: average weekly working hours per worker (log-transformed in elasticities).
method.control_variables: State total population, manufacturing as % of GDP, energy production, working-age population percentage, average household size, labor productivity (GDP per hour or similar), employment-to-population ratio, GDP per hour/capita, state environmentalism/political variables.

results.summary: Across multiple panel model specifications (fixed effects, random effects, Prais-Winsten PCSE, and hybrid models), average weekly working hours are positively associated with state-level CO2 emissions. Reported elasticities indicate that a 1% increase in average working hours is associated with roughly a 0.55%–0.67% increase in CO2 emissions depending on model and specification. Results are robust across models and sensitivity checks; total population and energy production are consistently positive and significant predictors of emissions, while some demographic controls (manufacturing % GDP, household size, working-age population %) are often non-significant. Hybrid models confirm a positive within-state association (coefficients ~0.633–0.635, p < 0.01). The authors interpret findings as evidence that reducing working hours could contribute to emission reductions (via scale and composition effects) while providing social benefits.

numerical_results.unit: % change in CO2 emissions per 1% change in working hours (elasticity)
